required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Physiological Effects of High-Flow Tracheal Oxygen Via An Modified Interface
clinical_study.official_title: Physiological Effects of High-Flow Tracheal Oxygen Via An Modified Interface in Tracheostomized Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Tracheostomy is often performed in patients after or anticipated prolonged mechanical ventilation, who are usually required oxygen therapy after discontinuation of mechanical ventilation.

detailed_description.textblock: Tracheostomy is often performed in patients after or anticipated prolonged mechanical ventilation, who are usually required oxygen therapy after discontinuation of mechanical ventilation.The high-flow tracheal (HFT) oxygen therapy in tracheostomized patients has been shown that can improve oxygenation,but can not induce positive end-expiratory pressure and elevation of end-expiratory lung volume. A modified HFT system by increasing expiratory resistance might induce PEEP and consequently elevate EELV.

primary_outcome.time_frame: the last 1 minutes of steady breathing during the standard or modified HFT.
primary_outcome.description: The patients was delivering the high flow oxygen via the standard and modified HFT interface for 20 minutes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in global and regional EELV
secondary_outcome.time_frame: the last 1 minutes of steady breathing during the standard or modified HFT.
secondary_outcome.description: The Electrical impedance tomography (EIT) was applied in monitoring the change of EELV at the bedside.

arm_group.description: The high-flow oxygen was delivered via tracheostomy using a standard HFT.
The high-flow oxygen was delivered via tracheostomy using a modified HFT.

intervention.description: The HFT was modified by increasing the expiratory resistance.
